body:
Eeek!  Will look at it tomorrow. It should be easy to fix though.

Thanks for testing.

OK I fixed that hopefully - I've put it in a fix-track-renames branch - can you have a go with that and see what you think?

Thanks

Nick

OK, now it is just half as slow as my implementation for the test case above, which still sounds expensive, considering the added code complexity.

````
23.94s  user 3.64s system 148% cpu 18.620 total
avg shared (code):         0 KB
avg unshared (data/stack): 0 KB
total (sum):               0 KB
max memory:                174552 MB
page faults from disk:     3370
other page faults:         694898
````
But, up to you.

Can you work out why it is slower? 

I note that it could be optimized further by only calculating the hashes of files which have a size which might match - that is probably the difference.

The trouble with your implementation is it has an [O(N^2) loop in](https://github.com/bep/rclone/blob/renames/fs/sync.go#L345), so if you, say, moved all your photos (10000 say) to a subdirectory and did a sync, then rclone would be doing 10000x10000 times around the loop

Will investigate some more tomorrow - past my bed time now, so probably none of the above makes any sense ;-)

>Can you work out why it is slower?

Asking me to debug your code is a tall order.

As to algorithmic complexity, I assume both solutions is  O(N^2)  in the worst case scenario and also assuming that the hashes are cached on the file level, it should not make much difference. The only way I see around that would be to implement some folder renaming logic.

I did a quick test of that too, moving a folder with the same 21 GB of files (~350 files) one level down.

The fix-renames branch:

```
Transferred:   12.008 kBytes (16 Bytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:               710
Transferred:            2
Elapsed time:     12m7.4s
191.83s  user 27.70s system 29% cpu 12:16.94 total
avg shared (code):         0 KB
avg unshared (data/stack): 0 KB
total (sum):               0 KB
max memory:                170560 MB
page faults from disk:     4153
other page faults:         694608
```

My code ((https://github.com/bep/rclone/tree/renames):

```
Transferred:   6.004 kBytes (10 Bytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 2
Transferred:            1
Elapsed time:     9m41.7s
187.39s  user 26.75s system 36% cpu 9:51.66 total
avg shared (code):         0 KB
avg unshared (data/stack): 0 KB
total (sum):               0 KB
max memory:                173552 MB
page faults from disk:     3374
other page faults:         686099
````

I'm checking out of this discussion. It is your project, you do as you please. 

I can understand and sympathise with the motivation to guard your own code, so I will say this in the nicest possible way:

Taking pull requests and repeatedly asking for improvements, saying "the only thing missing now is a test or two", and "oh, and could you add some documentation?". And when you finally "merge" it, you wipe out everything but the testing and the documentation without any discussion.

You should not get surprised when you don't get any "repeat Pull Requests" from people.

Ref. issue #888

Firstly I'd like to say thank you for your contribution.

I'm sorry you feel that I wiped out your code. I overstepped the mark in changing the code without discussing my concerns about it with you first.  Please accept my apologies.

Yes I am probably too picky about the code, and I'll try to take your comments on board for future pull requests.  I definitely haven't mastered the art of being an open source maintainer so I'm always willing to learn.

Thanks for your feedback

Nick

>I'm sorry you feel that I wiped out your code.

You did wipe out my code and replaced it with some hard to understand and buggy code. No feelings involved.
@hraban don't comment on something you have no clue about.
@bep If I lived by that rule, I would be mute.

@hraban @leonwilliams I'm going to give you the benefit of doubts and assume you really don't understand this situation.

This isn't about someone rejecting or deleting my code. I do that all the time to others. That is fine.

**This is all about wasting peoples time. This was an ongoing PR for weeks with "this looks very good, but could you just adjust this part over there ... " and then ... boom PR removed without any explanation.**

That is bad maintainer manners from @ncw -- and I would assume he has learned a lesson from it.
